Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Integrated Dynamic Spectrum Access for Throughput, Delay, and Fairness Enhancement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The central theme of this project is to investigate methodologies and theories to enhance throughput, delay, and fairness of cognitive radio networks via integrated dynamic spectrum access. The research will develop new methods to:
1) Extend spectrum sensing beyond just the presence and absence of the primary spectrum users' activities at certain spectrum bands/channels, but also their locations and transmit powers
2) Predict the primary spectrum user's activity and its interval using game theoretic and statistical learning approaches
3) Perform delay-aware spectrum management with a very comprehensive delay model considering all the factors that may affect the delivery latency of a packet, including the spectrum sensing delay, the transmission delay, the queuing delay, and the spectrum negotiation and scheduling delay
4) Share spectrum in a fair manner considering the tradeoff between fairness and throughput
5) Propose a delay-aware fair routing protocol for throughput optimization which jointly considers throughput, delay, and fairness along with dynamic spectrum management.

The project's focus on dynamic spectrum access is of high national interest and can create significant impact on spectral usage policies and related industries in the telecommunication and information technology sectors. The project will also encourage and include under-represented and minority students to be part of this activity, while extending education and outreach plans to undergraduates and K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addresses a few fundamental problems and challenges of dynamic spectrum access (DSA) to enable cognitive radio wireless networking (CRN). DSA provides a promising solution approach to the spectrum scarcity problem resulted from FCC's static spectrum assignment policy.  With the fast growth of the number of heterogeneous mobile devices and the advances of the rapid CR development, an environment that is full of communication devices with CR capabilities is foreseeable. In such a scenario how can we improve the performance of CRNs via a more effective and efficient exploitation of DSA? The central theme of this project is to investigate novel methodologies and theories to enhance throughput, delay, and fairness via integrated dynamic spectrum access. To achieve this objective the PIs not only define new problems that are critical to DSA but also propose novel technical approaches.

Intellectual Merits: During the project periods the PIs have carried out the following research activities: spectrum prediction (mainly primary user status prediction and spectrum available-interval prediction) via game theory and statistical learning approaches; delay modeling in DSA as well as delay-aware spectrum management for opportunistic routing in CRNs; fair spectrum sharing and its impact on spectrum management and media access control in CRNs; and CRN performance enhancement (delay, throughput, and fairness) via integrated spectrum sensing, prediction, assignment, and sharing. Particularly, we have developed i) robust collaborative spectrum sensing schemes that can make relatively accurate spectrum sensing decisions in spite of the existence of malicious secondary users; ii) an evolutionary game to address the problem of "which action (contributing to spectrum sensing or not) to take" and a coalition formation algorithm to decide which channel to sense when multiple primary channels exist; iii) an approach to fairly distribute spectrum bandwidths among different flows to mitigate the inter-flow contentions via spectrum sharing; iv) a mechanism based on Hidden Markov modeling for spectrum available-interval prediction and a mechanism based on Non-Stationary Hidden Markov Model for channel quality prediction in CRNs; v) cooperative relay selection schemes via optimal stopping theory and network formation game; vi) analytical results on the achievable transmission capacity in underlay CR networks; vii) a distributed back-pressure scheduling algorithm with opportunistic routing for throughput optimization in CRNs; and viii) self-collusion resistant auctions in heterogeneous spectrum markets for dynamic spectrum access. One can see that the PIs have tackled novel problems and achieved important results toward effective dynamic spectrum access. As many of the proposed methodologies employ knowledge from other domains such as machine learning and statistics, our designs may also help to motivate the corresponding domain-specific research.

Broader Impacts: This project was taken by a team of 4 professors (2 female professors) and more than 10 PhD students (about half of female and minority students) from three institutions, yielding 4 PhD thesis and more than 30 peer-reviewed publications. The PIs have been organizing a weekly group seminar open to all graduate students focusing on dynamic spectrum access and the research findings have been integrated into our networking courses via course projects and lecture presentations. The students were sent to focused workshops and conferences to present our findings. The novelty of the proposed project has strong societal impact as our rigorously proven and efficient solutions can serve as guidelines and backbone for promoting and establishing more flexible spectrum access policies and regulations. The approaches used in the project may be adopted by industry in their future designs for enhancing the service availability.
